newsitem.title: SPAIN: Latam, Caribbean form finance ministers' club.
newsitem.headline: Latam, Caribbean form finance ministers' club.

text.p: Latin American and Caribbean countries agreed on Wednesday to create a finance ministers club to discuss informally economic and financial issues, Chilean Finance Minister Eduardo Aninat said.

Aninat told Reuters that ministers and other officials from 14 countries representing the whole region had supported Chile's proposal to establish an informal group that will meet at least once a year to talk about the nuts and bolts of economic policy.

"The idea is to meet with no ties on, no communiques, agreements or formalities ... to explore ideas about what we finance ministers are facing," he said in an interview on the fringes of the Inter-American Development Bank's annual meeting.
Chile's proposal was backed by Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Trinidad and Tobago, Uruguay and Venezuela.
Costa Rica represented Central America while Trinidad and Tobago represented the Caribbean nations in the IADB.

The finance ministers' club is due to hold its first meeting on December 3 in Santiago, Chile, Aninat said. Mexico's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, offered to host a second round in 1998 in Cancun.
In their talks the ministers will analyse issues from various angles, from the design of policies, to how to deal with congress, or how to build popular support for their measures.

"For instance, in the first meeting Argentina and Chile will talk about tax reform, how such a reform is carried out, what happened to each of us when we undertook it, what is going on now and what we expect for the future," he said.
Other issues they are bound to tackle were social programmes, public financing and budget management.
In their breakfast meeting in Barcelona the officials heard Brazilian Planning Minister Antonio Kandir talk about the political groundwork needed to carry out economic reforms.

"Personally, I think it is very desirable to start generating an institutional memory of our own agendas, our own concerns about the delicate balance of combining economic reforms and their political implementation," Aninat added.
Chile's Finance Ministry will set up a secretariat for the club, which will also have technical support from the office of the IADB's chief economist, Ricardo Hausmann.
